Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Recommender Systems for Self-Actualization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Every day, we are confronted with an abundance of decisions that require us to choose from a seemingly endless number of choice options. Recommender systems are supposed to help us deal with this formidable task, but some scholars claim that these systems instead put us inside a "Filter Bubble" that severely limits our perspectives. This project investigates a new direction for recommender systems research with the main goal of supporting users in developing, exploring, and understanding their unique personal preferences. The project will develop a new type of recommender system: a Recommender System for Self-Actualization (RSSA), which will support decisions that have a resounding influence on our life (e.g., choosing an education or a job) where we do not want to just take the easiest option, but rather to develop ourselves into unique individuals with a strong sense of determination that we have chosen the right path.

In contrast to most existing recommender systems research, this project carefully considers the psychology of consumer choice processes and develops new types of recommendations to support these processes in novel ways (the RSSA features). The PI's team will develop a new recommender system outfitted with the capability to display a traditional Top-N recommendation list, plus each new RSSA feature. The team will then test the benefit of each RSSA feature against traditional Top-N recommendations in an online user experiment. This benefit will be measured by participants' subjective evaluation of the system and their usage behavior logs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to introduce the idea of ?self-actualization? into the field of recommender systems. The goal of these new recommender systems for self-actualization is to support users in developing, exploring, and understanding their unique personal preferences. As such, they are to support (rather than replace) users? decision-making practices. Specifically, we are developing and testing four features that provide lists of items that are explicitly not supposed to be ?good recommendations?, but instead show items that help users explore and understand their own tastes: a list of items that the user is predicted to hate, which allows users to correct mistakes in such predictions; a list of items for which the recommender has insufficient taste information to make an accurate prediction, which allows the system to learn more about users? unexplored preferences; a list of novel items, which allows adventurous users to try out new things; a list of controversial items, which allows users to develop unique tastes and enhance their unique personal and social identity.

Intellectual Merit: In contrast to most existing recommender systems research, our approach carefully considers the psychology of consumer choice processes (e.g. loss aversion, need for uniqueness) and develops new interaction paradigms to support these processes in novel ways. The warm reception of our concept-paper at the ACM Recommender Systems conference (which has already been cited 28 times) and our continuing conversations with industry and academic partners demonstrates that our ideas have already had a significant impact on the recommender systems research community.

Broader impacts: Our work has contributed to the development of recommender systems that allow users to have confidence in their life decisions, and help them to develop their personal tastes and styles. This is a particularly important goal in decisions that have a resounding influence on one?s life?e.g., choosing an education, a job, a health insurance plan, or a retirement fund?where we do not want people to just take the easiest option, but rather to develop themselves into unique individuals with a strong sense of determination that they have chosen the right path. A deep understanding of one?s own tastes is also important for cultural diversity?we want people to make lifestyle choices (e.g., their taste in music, movies and fashion) based on carefully developed personal tastes, rather than blindly followed recommendations.

An important realization that resulted from this project relates to the lack of a plug-and-play platform for live recommender system studies. We are currently underway to build such a platform.

This project has contributed significantly to the training of four PhD students and several MS students in Computer Science and Human-Centered Computing. The results of our work have been published in 5 conference and workshop papers. The project has resulted in new international collaborations with industry (The Home Depot, IBM Research Ireland) and academia (Eindhoven University of Technology, KU Leuven, Boise State University).
